item.title: When Is The Next Tarkov Wipe? | Summer 2024 EFT Wipe
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/next-escape-from-tarkov-wipe/

If you’re an avid Escape From Tarkov fan, then this question starts to lurk around inside your head once every so often: ‘When is the next Tarkov wipe?’ It’s a monumental event – that game-wide refresh that rests everyone back to level pegging in an instant, and it often brings white-hot content updates pouring into the game.

When is the next Escape From Tarkov wipe, and what is it going to look like?

What Is a Wipe In Tarkov?

When Escape From Tarkov ‘wipes’, every player is reset to level one, and their entire ‘stash’ – which is their collection weapons, equipment, money, and so on – is completely pushed back to the state it was when they first purchased the game. From there, players must once again climb the ladder, build their empire, complete early-game tasks, and rebuild their in-game hideout.

Read More: Is Escape From Tarkov Single-Player?

It’s a balancing mechanic, as it ensures that all players will at one point be matched in terms of equipment and opportunities. It also ensures that the game is kept somewhat fresh, as there is a point when the most experienced Escape From Tarkov players will simply have nothing left to do in the game but play it.

When a wipe hits, it typically brings with it a major update. These updates change the face of the game, often introducing entirely new maps, modes, characters, weapons – even new movement mechanics and physics elements.

Does Tarkov PvE Wipe?

In 2024, Battlestate Games opened up Tarkov’s PvE offering much more universally, giving players worldwide the ability to take advantage of this ‘offline’ platform. It works differently compared to the ‘traditional’ game as it doesn’t wipe automatically. Players can trigger a manual wipe whenever they’d like, but otherwise, they’re free to keep playing on the same character for as long as they like.

When Is The Next Tarkov Wipe?

It has been confirmed that the next Escape from Tarkov wipe will take place in August 2024. It’s expected that it’ll arrive in the third week of the month, starting from the 19th. It’ll be accompanied by an ambitious Twitch Drops campaign as usual.

Read More: Why Is Escape From Tarkov So Hard?

Here’s some data about the last Escape From Tarkov wipes, such as how long they lasted and when they took place:

  • December 27, 2023, Lasted 139 days
  • August 10, 2023, Lasted 225 days
  • December 28, 2022, Lasted 183 days
  • June 28, 2022, Lasted 198 days
  • December 12, 2021, Lasted 165 days
  • June 30, 2021, Lasted 188 days
  • December 24, 2020, Lasted 210 days
  • May 28, 2020, Lasted 214 days
  • October 27, 2019, Lasted 201 days

The current wipe, which went live at the end of December 2023, is the longest Tarkov wipe ever.

How To Tell When Tarkov Is Going To Wipe

Traditionally, Battlestate Games, the developer of Escape From Tarkov, will start scheduling special events just before a wipe is due to hit. In the past, Escape From Tarkov’s wipe events have been:

  • Maximum-value loot spawning in very specific locations on the map
  • All the game’s bosses spawn on the same map
  • Players spawning in poisoned and need to find a cure
  • Players spawning in with a ‘stim’ injector that could give them ‘super soldier abilities’
  • In-game traders offering their wares for just a few coins
  • Multiple loot airdrops falling in all at once

If the Tarkov events start ramping up, then you know that the next Escape From Tarkov wipe is starting soon.

Read Next: Is Escape From Tarkov Free To Play?

Frequently Asked Questions

  1. What was the longest wipe in Tarkov?
    • The longest wipe in Tarkov lasted 226 days (at the time of writing), running from December 28, 2023, to August 10, 2024.
  2. What was the shortest wipe in Tarkov?
    • The shortest wipe in Tarkov lasted just 60 days, running from October 27, 2017, to December 26, 2017.
  3. Do you lose everything when Tarkov wipes?
    • Yes, when Tarkov wipes, you lose everything including game progress, money, and stash contents.
  4. Does the Tarkov wipe delete your hideout?
    • Yes, when Tarkov wipes, you’ll lose your entire hideout and will need to rebuild it from scratch.
  5. When is the next Escape from Tarkov wipe?
    • See above!

Escape From Tarkov is available exclusively on PC.

item.title: Dead Rising Deluxe Remaster Won’t Let You Take Erotic Photos
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/dead-rising-deluxe-remaster-erotic/

Fans of Dead Rising, the 2006 zombie apocalypse-fuelled title, are dismayed that they’ll no longer earn points in-game for snapping ‘erotic’ photos. Well, perhaps ‘dismayed’ is a little strong, but some tongue-in-cheek comments are being made about the ‘too PC’ removal of ‘Erotica’ points in the Dead Rising Deluxe Remaster.

In a recent developer diary, covered first by Famitsu, Capcom revealed the decision to strip points for erotic photos clean out of the upcoming game, which is set to be released on September 19.

Keep It Clean

Admittedly, it was a little creepy in 2006. Let’s say you managed to snap a picture of a female zombie laying on their back, taking advantage of an angle that let you peek up their dress. This would earn you ‘erotica’ points, boosting the value of your photos. Everything from cleavage to suggestive elements earned you these points, but that won’t be the case going into the Dead Rising Deluxe Remaster.

Capcom has confirmed that while photography remains a front-and-centre element of the game, getting points for lewd angles is no longer a thing.

There are high expectations for the Dead Rising Deluxe Remaster. It has been boosted with several quality-of-life improvements, such as auto-saving, and most of the game’s environment – which is set in and around a shopping mall – has been fully refreshed.

Are you excited about heading back to Willamette in the Dead Rising Deluxe Remaster?

For more Insider Gaming coverage, check out the news that all Black Ops 6 campaign cutscenes have leaked online

item.title: Best Summer Crops In Stardew Valley
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/best-summer-crops-in-stardew-valley/1100-6525175/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Growing and harvesting crops is one of the best ways to make money in Stardew Valley and the Summer season has a few different great options to maximize your profits. Summer has multiple standout options for making money, but it also has a few crops that really aren't worth growing due to low profits.

Best Summer crops

The best crops to grow in Summer for profit are blueberries, melons, starfruit, and red cabbage. Starfruit seeds are only profitable if bought from the Oasis shop or made from a seed maker and red cabbage isn't available at Pierre's until Year 2. The absolute best option is the blueberries, since the plants continue to reproduce throughout the season, so you don't have to buy more seeds. Each plant gives multiple blueberries each harvest, drastically increasing the crop's overall value.

While it can be tempting to only focus on the most profitable crops, if you are going down the community center path, you will need a variety of crops to complete the bundles needed to unlock the Greenhouse.

Similar to cauliflower in Spring, melons are profitable, but due to their long growth time, you will only get two paydays from them during the season. If you want to spread out your income a bit better, it's good to mix in a few crops with shorter turnaround times. Corn is also a great crop to plant. While it isn't as profitable for each harvest, corn continues to produce and it's a hybrid crop, able to grow during Summer and Fall. That means you can plant a cornfield at the beginning of Summer, and it will produce corn all the way through the end of Fall.

Below you can find a table containing every Spring crop, the cost of their seeds, time it takes to harvest, and sell prices. All of these numbers don't include potential bonuses, like faster growth time or better sell prices. Seed costs are based on Pierre's Store, unless it's noted that they come from a different vendor.

CropSeed CostGrowth Time (days)Sell Price

Normal: 50G

Silver: 62G

Gold: 75G

Iridium: 100G

Poppy100G7

Normal: 140G

item.title: Monster Hunter Wilds weapon trailer – ‘Long Sword’
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gematsu.com/2024/08/monster-hunter-wilds-weapon-trailer-long-sword
  • PC
  • PS5
  • Xbox Series

A weapon that excels at swift movements and combos.

Capcom has released a new weapon trailer for Monster Hunter Wilds introducing the Long Sword.

Monster Hunter Wilds is due out for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series, and PC via Steam in 2025.

Watch the trailer below.

Weapon Overview: Long Sword

“For those who have studied the blade. Embrace the flow of the hunt and counter attacks in the blink of an eye. Charge your Spirit Gauge to empower your attacks. With Focus Mode, slice with absolute precision and seal the monster’s fate.”

English

Japanese

item.title: Fallout London's volunteer modding team to launch as a new indie studio
item.content:encoded:
https://www.eurogamer.net/fallout-londons-volunteer-modding-team-to-launch-as-a-new-indie-studio

"Fallout London has been a great springboard for that."

Team Folon – the volunteer squad of developers who have released the ambitious Fallout 4 mod, Fallout London – is set to launch itself as a new indie studio.

Talking to the BBC (via PCGN), Folon's project lead, Dean Carter, admitted that "as much as I love the fact that this is a free project - that we can offer this thing for free for all the community - free doesn't pay our bills".

"What has been great for us is that a lot of people who have really enjoyed [Fallout London] have donated to us, and we're channelling that into Team Folon, which is what we're going to be moving into," Carter said.

"We should hopefully launch our own indie games company which will allow us to come up with our own ideas, create our own games, and work [...] without having to speak to anyone above us, such as Bethesda, or anything like that.

"It'll be completely our own thing and we can create a game that we want, that we think the community will enjoy. Fallout London has been a great springboard for that."

As for what's next for Fallout London?

"Fallout London will continue until we have all the content which we had to cut for the release. We have another ending, which we call the wild card ending - that will come out in one of the future patches. That's not going to happen soon; we can see ourselves working until the end of the year.

"We don't have ulterior motives. We wanted to do something that was fun [during lockdown], we've made something that's fun, and people have found it fun, so for us we've achieved that goal so we're very happy about it, and the reception."

Asked if Bethesda had reached out to Team Folon following all the positive coverage of Fallout London, Carter simply said: "Um, no. No, we haven't."

"There hasn't been any communication, which is strange, because we've now had communication with other people in the industry, and what I guess would be seen as their competitors. They've reached out to us, and we've spoken to them, but Bethesda themselves have not spoken to us at all, no."

He did, however, add that as this was a fan-made mod created entirely on Bethesda's own IP, Team Folon in no way believes it is "entitled" to an audience with Bethesda.

A hotfix for Fallout: London to address crashing issues is still on the way, with developer Team Folon planning a "huge" patch soon after.

The game-size fan-made mod for Fallout 4 set in the English capital released at the end of July, but players have experienced a high number of crashes and issues, including Eurogamer's Ian Higton when he streamed his playthrough.

Team Folon has since promised a fix was on the way and, in a new statement on its Discord, has reiterated its plans for the future.

item.title: GTA 6 won't be on a subscription service on day one because Take-Two's "decisions are rational," says CEO
item.content:encoded:
https://www.eurogamer.net/gta-6-wont-be-on-a-subscription-service-on-day-one-because-take-twos-decisions-are-rational-says-ceo

"It is our job to outperform the industry, and the only way to do that is to generate big hits."

Take-Two Interactive boss Strauss Zelnick said the company is not tempted to put its game on subscription services like Xbox Game Pass on day one because "our decisions are rational".

Talking to our sister site GamesIndustry.biz, Zelnick said that whilst he accepted "offering a frontline title with a premium price in a subscription service, day and date, will push consumers to that subscription service for at least a period of time", "it won't affect [Take-Two's] decisions [not to offer AAA games on subscription services on day one]".

With "15 immersive core" games on Take-Two's books for 2026 and 2027 - one of which is GTA 6, of course - as well as one indie, five mobile games, and three remasters, Zelnick says it's his company's "job to outperform the industry, and the one way to do that is to generate big hits, and I think we have all the necessary elements to deliver that."

"There are modest tailwinds which are positive," he concludes. "It is our job to outperform the industry, and the only way to do that is to generate big hits, and I think we have all the necessary elements to deliver that."

Yesterday, we reported that Zelnick asked if fans could please give the new Borderlands movie "a chance" because "a lot of people worked really hard on it".

Zelnick was asked about the film's less-than-stellar early reviews during its Q1 earnings call, and whilst he called the "look and the feel" of the movie "terrific", Zelnick told investors that its performance "wouldn't have a financial impact" on Take-Two or, indeed, the Borderlands franchise itself.

item.title: Borderlands Movie Bad, BotW Players Find An Amazing Glitch, And More Of The Week's Top News
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/borderlands-movie-quakecon-helldivers-news-games-1851618210

This week, we reported on diligent, game-breaking Tears of the Kingdom players figuring out how to attain an item they’ve been trying to acquire for ages. Also, after years in production hell, the Borderlands movie is finally here and critics are not liking it! We also rounded up the biggest announcements out of QuakeCon, and more. Read on! 

Getting the Master Sword in The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom feels great. After dozens of hours of dealing with ugly fused weapons and broken gear, you finally get the sword of legend. But it’s still far from perfect. While it can’t break, it can lose its power and have to recharge. The Master Sword from the game’s opening prologue doesn’t have that same weakness, though, and players have spent months trying to find a way to get that version instead. - Ethan Gach Read More

Today is the start of Diablo IV’s Season of the Infernal Hordes. It adds a new mode, quests, and a ton of rebalancing. It also accidentally let players carry over their Legendary Tempering recipes from last season, and Blizzard is being generous and giving the bug a pass this time around. - Ethan Gach Read More

After a very long wait, the live-action Borderlands movie finally arrives in theaters this weekend. But before that, the movie was screened for fans and critics in Los Angeles. And, based on the first impressions being posted online, the Borderlands movie sounds like a complete mess. - Zack Zwiezen Read More

A new and powerful weapon added to Diablo IV’s latest season suddenly led to some players leveling up incredibly fast, with one player jumping over 30 levels after one boss kill. Blizzard has since tracked down the cause of this bug and released a temporary fix. - Zack Zwiezen Read More

Borderlands 3 launched in 2019, so you might not expect an update for the looter shooter in 2024. However, possibly due to the recent release of the (terrible) movie, Gearbox has put out a new, small, but genuinely awesome patch for Borderlands 3. - Zack Zwiezen Read More

Helldivers 2 received a big new patch today ahead of its Freedom’s Flame Warbond later this week and it has players feeling burned and betrayed. The update brought big changes to the existing flamethrower which is no longer melting heavily-armored Charger enemies with ease and the community is already in open revolt over the unexpected crackdown on intergalactic arson. - Ethan Gach Read More

Earlier today at QuakeCon 2024, id Software announced a bunch of Doom-related news, including a brand new way to play the first two classic shooters, mod tools for Eternal, and more. - Zack Zwiezen Read More

EA College Football 25 is one of the biggest and most popular games of 2024. So it’s no surprise that the game is continuing to receive a lot of support, including a new free update that adds new uniforms, plays, and makes a bunch of changes to abilities, athlete recruitment, and more. - Zack Zwiezen Read More

The high-school zombie hack-and-slash revival is almost upon us. The LolliPop Chainsaw remaster, called RePOP, is coming out earlier than expected with a price tag that has some fans scratching their heads. - Ethan Gach Read More

Disney’s popular streaming service is set to receive yet another price hike, marking the fourth increase for the streamer since it launched in 2019. The new ad-free tier of Disney+ will soon cost $16 a month. It comes as Disney and other companies continue to try and squeeze more profit out of expensive-to-run streaming services and before some recent hits, like Inside Out 2, arrive at home this fall. - Zack Zwiezen Read More
